page.title: 05FARMING
page.content: Most of the land lies between 150 metres and is disected by steeply sloping river valleys which are mostly wooded. The overall impression of the area is the predominance of grass. Because of the shorter growing season the farmers in this area do not attempt to grow cereal crops. Instead the grassland is improved where possible by liming the acid soil, spreading fertiliser and re-seeding. The grass is used to graze sheep and cattle. The highest areas on the slopes of Moelfre Isaf are left unsown but are enclosed with fences in order to graze livestock. Farmers in the area are beginning to take advantage of grants from the{E.E.C.}to begin improving this upland pasture. Farms in the area depend entirely on the raising of livestock - sheep and cattle - for wool and meat.
